rules.title: Phishing Detection via Office Process Spawning Command Shells
rules.description: Detects potential phishing activity by identifying Office processes spawning command shells
falsepositives: Legitimate Office documents spawning command shells for automated tasks or scripting

rules.title: PowerShell Execution Detection
rules.description: Detects PowerShell execution activity using process creation events
falsepositives: PowerShell usage for automation or troubleshooting

rules.title: Detection: Process Injection
rules.description: Detected Process Injection activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.description: Detected Create or Modify System Process activity via NLP pattern matching

rules.description: Detects Exfiltration Over C2 Channel activity via NLP pattern matching
falsepositives: Command line tools using similar flags for non-malicious purposes

rules.description: Detects exploitation of public-facing applications via NLP pattern matching

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Write-Host 'This is a phishing simulation: Please do not enter any sensitive information.'"
attacks.description: Basic phishing simulation using PowerShell to display a message.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a phishing simulation message to the user.

attacks.command: cmd.exe /c echo This is a phishing email simulation > %TEMP%\phishingsim.txt
attacks.description: Intermediate phishing simulation creating a text file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a text file named phishingsim.txt in the user's temp directory with a phishing simulation message.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Windows.Forms; $form = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Form; $form.Text = 'Phishing Simulation'; $label = New-Object System.Windows.Forms.Label; $label.Text = 'Please do not enter sensitive information.'; $form.Controls.Add($label); $form.ShowDialog()"
attacks.description: Advanced phishing simulation using PowerShell to create a GUI form.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a GUI window with a phishing simulation message.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a phishing test email.' | mail -s 'Test Email' user@example.com
attacks.description: Simulate sending a phishing email using the mail command.
attacks.expected_behavior: An email is sent to the specified address with the subject 'Test Email' and the body 'This is a phishing test email.'

attacks.description: Download a webpage that could be associated with phishing activities.
attacks.expected_behavior: The webpage is downloaded and saved as /tmp/phishing-test.html.

attacks.description: Simulate submitting a form with credentials to a phishing site.
attacks.expected_behavior: A POST request is sent to the specified URL with JSON data containing an email and password.

attacks.description: Lists files in the temporary directory using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files and directories in the user's temporary directory

attacks.description: Creates an archive of files in the temporary directory using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a ZIP archive in the temporary directory containing files from the same directory

attacks.description: Downloads a local file using PowerShell's Invoke-WebRequest
attacks.expected_behavior: Copies the content of a local file to another file in the temporary directory

attacks.description: Lists all running processes using PowerShell on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running processes.

attacks.description: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World' using PowerShell on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt is created in /tmp with 'Hello World' as its content.

attacks.description: Compresses the test.txt file into a zip archive named test.zip in the /tmp directory, overwriting any existing file with the same name using PowerShell on Linux.
attacks.expected_behavior: A zip file named test.zip is created in /tmp, containing test.txt.

attacks.description: Basic process injection using PowerShell to start notepad.exe and inject calc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad.exe and calc.exe will be started, demonstrating process injection

attacks.description: Intermediate process injection using cmd.exe to start a new cmd.exe process and inject calc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cmd.exe process will be started, and calc.exe will be injected, demonstrating process injection

attacks.command: powershell -Command "&{Add-Type -TypeDefinition 'using System;using System.Runtime.InteropServices;[DllImport("kernel32")]public static extern IntPtr OpenProcess(int dwDesiredAccess,bool bInheritHandle,string lpName);';Start-Process -FilePath 'C:\Windows\System32\notepad.exe' -ArgumentList '/c calc.exe'}"
attacks.description: Advanced process injection using PowerShell to define a new type and start notepad.exe, then inject calc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: Notepad.exe will be started, and calc.exe will be injected, demonstrating advanced process injection

attacks.description: Inject code into a running process using gdb
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attach to the process with PID 1234 and inject code into it.

attacks.description: Inject code into a running process using ptrace
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will attach to the process with PID 1234 and inject code into it.

attacks.description: Inject code into a running process using ldpreload
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will load the malicious library into the legitimate binary.

attacks.description: Create a new system service using sc.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: A new system service named TestService will be created

attacks.description: Start the newly created system service using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The TestService system service will be started

attacks.description: Create a new process using PowerShell
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cmd.exe process will be created

attacks.description: Start the SSH service, demonstrating the creation of a system process.
attacks.expected_behavior: The SSH service will start, allowing remote connections to the system.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing, allowing for the modification of system processes through scheduled jobs.
attacks.expected_behavior: The default editor will open, allowing the user to add, modify, or delete cron jobs.

attacks.description: Apply changes from the sysctl configuration file, demonstrating the modification of system process parameters.
attacks.expected_behavior: System parameters will be updated according to the configurations in /etc/sysctl.conf.

attacks.description: Starting the telnet service to demonstrate application layer protocol usage for potential C2.
attacks.expected_behavior: The telnet service will be started, allowing for potential command and control communication over the application layer protocol.

attacks.description: Using PowerShell to create a file in the temp directory, simulating data exfiltration or C2 communication.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named test.txt will be created in the temp directory with the content 'Hello World', demonstrating how PowerShell can be used for application layer protocol activities.

attacks.description: Using certutil to download a file from a URL, simulating a C2 channel over HTTP.
attacks.expected_behavior: The file test.txt will be downloaded from the specified URL and saved to the temp directory, demonstrating the use of application layer protocols for command and control.

attacks.description: Basic command to listen on port 8080 using netcat, simulating a C2 channel
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will listen on port 8080 and wait for incoming connections

attacks.description: Intermediate command to send a JSON payload to a web server using curl, mimicking C2 communication
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will send a JSON payload to the specified web server

attacks.command: python -c 'import socket; s=socket.socket(socket.AF_INET,socket.SOCK_STREAM); s.connect(("example.com",8080)); s.send(b"Hello, World!"); s.close()'
attacks.description: Advanced command to establish a socket connection to a remote server and send a message, simulating C2 activity
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will establish a socket connection to the remote server and send a message

attacks.description: Basic command execution using cmd.exe to create a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the user's temp directory with the content 'Hello'.

attacks.description: Intermediate command using PowerShell to display a message box.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a message box with the text 'Hello, World!'.

attacks.command: powershell -Command "[System.IO.File]::WriteAllText('%TEMP%\example.txt', 'This is an example file.'); Get-Content -Path '%TEMP%\example.txt'"
attacks.description: Advanced command demonstrating file creation and reading using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named example.txt in the temp directory with specified content and then reads and displays the content.

attacks.description: Basic command execution using bash to create a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Intermediate command execution using bash to create a directory and file
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory named testdir in the /tmp directory and a file named test.txt inside it with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Advanced command execution using bash to list directory contents and create a file
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists the contents of the /tmp directory and creates a file named test.txt in the /tmp directory with the content 'Hello World'

attacks.description: Encode a file using certutil to obscure its contents
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will encode the test.txt file and save it as encoded.txt in the temp directory

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to decode a Base64 string and save it to a file, demonstrating obfuscated information
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will decode the Base64 string and save it to a file named obfuscated.txt in the temp directory

attacks.description: Create a file with obfuscated information and hide it using the attrib command
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will create a file named obfuscated_file.txt in the temp directory, write Hello World to it, and then hide the file using the attrib command

attacks.command: echo 'This is a test file' > test.txt; base64 test.txt > encoded_test.txt
attacks.description: Creates a test file, then uses base64 to encode it, demonstrating basic obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A base64 encoded file named encoded_test.txt will be created in the current directory.

attacks.command: tar -czf compressed_test.tar.gz test.txt; base64 compressed_test.tar.gz > encoded_compressed_test.txt
attacks.description: Compresses a test file using tar and gzip, then uses base64 to encode the compressed file, demonstrating intermediate obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A base64 encoded file named encoded_compressed_test.txt will be created in the current directory, containing the compressed test file.

attacks.command: echo 'This is a test script' > test.sh; chmod +x test.sh; base64 test.sh > encoded_test.sh; gzip encoded_test.sh
attacks.description: Creates a test script, makes it executable, then uses base64 to encode it and gzip to compress the encoded script, demonstrating advanced obfuscation.
attacks.expected_behavior: A compressed and base64 encoded file named encoded_test.sh.gz will be created in the current directory, containing the executable test script.

attacks.description: Encode a test file using certutil
attacks.expected_behavior: The test file will be encoded and saved as a new file

attacks.description: Simulate sending encoded data over a C2 channel using net.exe
attacks.expected_behavior: The encoded data will be sent over the specified port

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to compress a file, then simulate sending the compressed data over a C2 channel
attacks.expected_behavior: The file will be compressed, then the compressed data will be sent over the specified port

attacks.description: Basic example of exfiltrating data by encoding it with base64 and saving it to a temporary file, then decoding it to simulate data exfiltration over a C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command encodes 'Sensitive_Data' with base64, saves it to a temporary file, and then decodes it back to its original form, simulating data exfiltration without actually sending it over a network.

attacks.description: Intermediate example searching for configuration files in /etc that contain 'password' or 'username', redirecting the output to a temporary file to simulate exfiltration of sensitive configuration data.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command searches for configuration files containing sensitive keywords and saves the findings to a temporary file, demonstrating how an attacker might exfiltrate sensitive data from system configurations.

attacks.description: Advanced example creating a tarball of sensitive system directories (/etc and /var/log), compressing it, and then encoding it with base64 to simulate exfiltrating system data over a C2 channel.
attacks.expected_behavior: This command demonstrates a more sophisticated exfiltration technique by archiving and compressing sensitive system data, then encoding it for potential transmission, highlighting the risk of significant data loss if such an attack were successful.

attacks.description: Attempt to add a new user to the system, simulating a potential exploit of a public-facing application's user management functionality.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to add a new user, which could be detected as a potential exploit of a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Use PowerShell to create a file in the temp directory, simulating the delivery of an exploit payload to a public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: A file named exploit.txt is created in the temp directory, which could be detected as part of an exploit attempt against a public-facing application.

attacks.description: Attempt to download and execute a file from a URL, simulating an exploit of a public-facing application's vulnerability to malicious downloads.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command attempts to download a file and execute it, which could be detected as an exploit of a public-facing application. Note: This command is for testing in isolated environments only and should not be used with actual malicious payloads.

attacks.description: Basic command to simulate a request to a potentially vulnerable public-facing application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends an HTTP request to the specified URL with a User-Agent header, simulating a basic exploit attempt.

attacks.description: Intermediate command that uses wget to simulate an exploit attempt against a public API endpoint.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command downloads the content from the specified API endpoint, simulating an exploit that targets API vulnerabilities.

attacks.description: Advanced command using netcat to simulate a manual HTTP request to a potentially vulnerable application.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command sends a raw HTTP request to the specified server and port, simulating a more sophisticated exploit attempt.

attacks.description: Lists all user accounts on the system, potentially useful for identifying targets for credential dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of user accounts on the system.

attacks.description: Attempts to access the SAM file, which contains hashed Windows credentials, using PowerShell.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays information about the SAM file if accessible, demonstrating an attempt to access credential storage.

attacks.description: Uses the registry command to save the SAM hive to a file, which could be used for offline credential dumping.
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves the SAM registry hive to a file named 'sam' in the temp directory, which could be used for further analysis or exploitation.

attacks.description: Dumping the passwd file to extract user credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays the contents of the passwd file, including user credentials

attacks.description: Using getent to extract user credentials from system databases
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays user credentials from system databases

attacks.description: Searching for password strings within /etc/ directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays files and lines containing the string 'password' within the /etc/ directory

attacks.description: Lists all running services on the local machine, which can be used for network service discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running services.

attacks.description: Displays detailed information about the TCP/IP configuration of the local machine, including network services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays detailed TCP/IP configuration information.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to list all running services on the local machine, which can be used for network service discovery.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of running services.

attacks.description: Basic network service discovery using TCP SYN scanning on a specific IP address.
attacks.expected_behavior: Identifies open TCP ports and services on the target IP address.

attacks.description: Intermediate network service discovery using UDP scanning on a specific port (DNS) of an IP address.
attacks.expected_behavior: Detects if the DNS service is open and responding on the target IP address.

attacks.description: Advanced network service discovery using OS detection on a specific IP address.
attacks.expected_behavior: Attempts to identify the operating system and other characteristics of the target host.

attacks.description: This command uses PowerShell to compress all files in the Public Documents folder into a zip archive located in the TEMP directory, demonstrating basic archiving of collected data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive in the TEMP directory containing files from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: This command changes the directory to Public Documents, then uses the tar command to create a gzip archive of all files in that directory, saved to the TEMP directory, demonstrating an intermediate level of archiving collected data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a tar.gz archive in the TEMP directory containing files from the Public Documents folder.

attacks.description: This advanced command uses PowerShell to load the System.IO.Compression.FileSystem assembly and then creates a zip archive from the Public Documents folder, demonstrating a more complex method of archiving collected data.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive in the TEMP directory containing files from the Public Documents folder, using .NET classes for compression.

attacks.description: Basic example of archiving collected data using tar.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a compressed archive of the specified directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate example using zip for archiving.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a zip archive of the specified directory.

attacks.description: Advanced example using 7z for archiving with high compression.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a highly compressed 7z archive of the specified directory.

attacks.description: Create a daily task named 'Test Task' that writes 'Hello' to a file in the temp directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new task is created and can be seen in the Task Scheduler, running daily and writing to the specified file without causing harm.

attacks.description: Query the Task Scheduler for a task named 'Test Task'.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command lists the details of the 'Test Task' if it exists, demonstrating how to query scheduled tasks.

attacks.description: Delete the 'Test Task' task. The /f option forces the deletion without prompting.
attacks.expected_behavior: The 'Test Task' is deleted from the Task Scheduler. This command demonstrates task deletion and requires caution as it permanently removes tasks.

attacks.description: Open the cron table for editing to add a new job
attacks.expected_behavior: The default editor will open, allowing the user to add a new cron job

attacks.description: Add a new cron job that runs a script daily at midnight
attacks.expected_behavior: A new cron job will be added, which can be verified using the `crontab -l` command

attacks.description: Remove a cron job that runs a specific script
attacks.expected_behavior: The specified cron job will be removed, which can be verified using the `crontab -l` command

attacks.description: Capture keyboard input and save to file
attacks.expected_behavior: Saves keyboard input to a file in the temp directory

attacks.description: List saved credentials
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists saved credentials

attacks.description: List files in temp directory
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files in the temp directory

attacks.description: List all input devices
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will list all input devices connected to the system.

attacks.description: Record user input
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will record user input and save it to a file named test.xrm.

attacks.description: Display keyboard layout
attacks.expected_behavior: The command will display the keyboard layout and potentially capture input.

attacks.description: Lists all running services on the local machine, which can be used to identify potential remote services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Displays a list of currently running services on the system.

attacks.command: sc create MyTestService binpath= "C:\\Windows\\System32\\svchost.exe -k netsvcs" start= auto
attacks.description: Creates a new service named MyTestService that runs svchost.exe. This demonstrates creating a service that could potentially interact with remote services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a new service named MyTestService which will start automatically. The service executes svchost.exe with the netsvcs parameter.

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to filter and display only the services that are currently running, which can help in identifying active remote services.
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists all services on the system that are currently in a running state.

attacks.description: Basic SSH command to list files on a remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: Lists files on the remote host

attacks.description: Intermediate SSH command to create a directory on a remote host
attacks.expected_behavior: Creates a directory on the remote host

attacks.description: Advanced SSH command to download a payload from a remote URL
attacks.expected_behavior: Downloads a payload from a remote URL, but redirects output to /dev/null to avoid execution

attacks.description: Capture the screen using PowerShell and save it as a PNG file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: The command captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG file named 'screenshot.png' in the user's temporary directory.

attacks.description: Open mspaint with a specified size to potentially capture and edit a screenshot, though this command itself does not capture the screen. It's a basic example and might need additional steps to actually capture and save the screen.
attacks.expected_behavior: Opens mspaint with a window size of 1920x1080, potentially for screenshot editing or capture, but does not automatically capture the screen.

attacks.description: An advanced PowerShell command that captures the screen, utilizing Reflection to load necessary assemblies and then saves the screenshot as a PNG file in the temporary directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures the entire screen and saves it as 'advanced_screenshot.png' in the user's temporary directory, demonstrating a more complex use of PowerShell for screen capture.

attacks.description: Basic screen capture using scrot, saving the screenshot to the user's home directory.
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures the entire screen and saves it as a PNG image in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Intermediate screen capture using scrot, allowing the user to select a region of the screen to capture.
attacks.expected_behavior: Prompts the user to select a region of the screen, then captures and saves that region as a PNG image in the user's home directory.

attacks.description: Advanced screen capture using scrot, adjusting the quality of the screenshot.
attacks.expected_behavior: Captures the entire screen, adjusts the quality of the screenshot to 100%, and saves it as a PNG image in the user's home directory.

attacks.command: reg add "HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a registry key to run a command at user login
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry key is added under HKCU to execute a command that writes 'test' to a file in the temp directory upon user login

attacks.command: reg add "HKLM\Software\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\Run" /v test /t REG_SZ /d "cmd.exe /c echo test > %TEMP%\test.txt" /f
attacks.description: Adds a registry key to run a command at system startup
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry key is added under HKLM to execute a command that writes 'test' to a file in the temp directory upon system startup

attacks.description: Uses PowerShell to add a registry key to run a command at user login
attacks.expected_behavior: A registry key is added under HKCU to execute a command that writes 'test' to a file in the temp directory upon user login

attacks.description: Adds a cron job to touch a file named 'malicious_file' in /tmp every minute, simulating persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named 'malicious_file' will be created or updated in /tmp every minute.

attacks.description: Adds a cron job to touch a file named 'reboot_file' in /tmp at system reboot, simulating persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named 'reboot_file' will be created in /tmp at system reboot.

attacks.description: Adds a command to the user's profile to touch a file named 'login_file' in /tmp upon login, simulating persistence.
attacks.expected_behavior: A new file named 'login_file' will be created or updated in /tmp upon user login.

attacks.description: Downloads a malicious file using certutil and executes it
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be downloaded and executed

attacks.description: Executes a malicious PowerShell script using Invoke-Item
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious PowerShell script will be executed

attacks.description: Creates a malicious file using echo and opens it using notepad
attacks.expected_behavior: The malicious file will be created and opened using notepad

attacks.description: Basic example of executing a malicious script
attacks.expected_behavior: The command executes a script located in /tmp, simulating user execution of a malicious file.

attacks.description: Intermediate example downloading, making executable, and running a malicious file
attacks.expected_behavior: This command downloads a file, makes it executable, and then runs it, demonstrating a more complex scenario of user execution of a malicious file.

attacks.description: Advanced example using curl to download and pipe a malicious script to bash for execution
attacks.expected_behavior: This command uses curl to download a script and pipes it directly to bash for execution, simulating a sophisticated method of user execution of a malicious file.
